UNDERWATER, through shafts of light, white limbs are FLAILING. The MAN struggles, alone. Bubbles stream upward He breaks the surface and gasps for air. He begins to swim. His massive arms and shoulders grab at tide in large, hard strokes. His legs and feet are buried beneath the dark ocean water.
2 A floating tenement. A crane LOWERS a fishing net into the water. The MAN swim into it. The net is RAISED as he lays, motionless, within grip.

3 The crane swings around with the MAN in the net. He is EMPTIED out onto the deck like a fish. AHIVERING on the rotting wooden planks he FLIPS himself o on his stomach. Slowly, using the palms of his hands, he DRAGS his trunk and withered limbs across the deck in a labored lobster-walk. He uses his chest muscles to swing his legs around the ed of the boat. They dangle like pieces of rope, his feet wh and flaccid. A towel, a bottle and a glass are wordlessly placed next him by a CREW PERSON. He pours himself a generous amount scotch and begins drinking.
The same MAN is illuminated by the light of a single cand He is dancing, holding on tightly to a WOMAN.

Though the light is dim it is clear that he is clean shav with his hair neatly trimmed. Their connection is powerful and alive. They stop dancing overwhelmed with mutual desire. He holds the WOMAN's face in his hands and KISSES it all over, moving into a realm of feeling that is foreign to h He kisses her passionately on the mouth.

Oh, my dear... His fingers run softly over the outside of her breasts. S begins to undo the back of her dress and slips it down ar her ankles. Wearing only her tight corset she brings his hands to the laces and together they undo it.
(whispering softly)
It's all right, darling. It's all right.
5 OSCAR, a manservant, is carrying both a silver tray and a pair of pants over his extended arm.
Oscar! Where the devil are you? Deftly, Oscar opens the door to a spacious bedroom.
My apologies, Mr. Roosevelt.

6 There with his bare legs, muscular and lean, sporting bla socks held up with garters is FRANKLIN DELANO ROOSEVELT, He projects a natural elegance and the confidence of a ma who can have anything he wants. Right now... he wants his pants.
I've been standing here for five minutes. Oscar offers the tray to Franklin which bear cuff links a Tiffany watch which Franklin grabs.
Did you sleep well, sir?
Don't remember. That's good, isn't it?
Yes, sir. Franklin takes his pants from Oscar and steps into them, pulling the suspenders up and over his shoulders. 7

Striding into the dining room, Franklin lifts a silver li off a breakfast plate. He dismisses it and instead pours himself a cup of coffee from a silver pot on the sideboar He overhears a voice from the nearby sitting room.

I could not be more delighted to have received your most charming letter. It has been far too long since we last corresponded. However, it is with great reluctance I must decline your kind speaking invitation... 8
ELEANOR ROOSEVELT, 34, is dictating a letter. Her enormou eyes, liquid and blue, reveal a woman of extraordinary intelligence and depth.

Unfortunately, I would be of little assistance to the Junior Assistance League. Particularly if my purpose were to appear as an alumna who is gifted at public speaking. She is dictating to LUCY MERCER, 27, deeply feminine with head of soft dark hair and an accommodating nature. She i Eleanor's social secretary and closest friend. She is also the WOMAN dancing with Franklin the night bef
And what do you really want me to say?
Thank you and if you ask again I shall scream?
They share a laugh -- which is not shared by the homely rumpled mess of a man draped over a sofa in the corner. LOUIS

Why don't you ask your husband for some pointers? He's a pretty gifted public speaker, don't you think? LOUIS HOWE, 48, is a wizened man of limited stature and unlimited soul. Franklin's political advisor extraordinai part consiglieri and part priest. He is the mastermind be what he believes will be the greatest political career of twentieth century. He gets up and leans in closely to Eleanor. A cigarette d off his lip and the smoke rises up and curls in her face. LOUIS
You should get out once in a while. Accepting that invitation would be good for Franklin's career. ELEANOR
Mr. Howe, wouldn't you be more comfortable waiting for my husband outside? LOUIS
In the street, Mrs. Roosevelt? ELEANOR
If you like. Eleanor smiles oh-so politely at Louis, as Franklin enter from the dining room. FRANKLIN
I see it's not even eight a.m. and already the gloves are off. (kissing Eleanor on the cheek) Good morning, Babs. Hello, Miss Mercer.   L UCY
Good morning, sir. Quickly, she lowers her eyes to her work. LOUIS
(annoyed) You're late. Honestly, why do you enjoy keeping people waiting?
Because they always seem more grateful to see me when I arrive. He leans in and kisses Eleanor on the cheek.
Have a lovely day, Babs.
Should I expect you for dinner?
I have the Navy reception this evening. I'll be home quite late. Unless you've changed your mind about coming? Louis looks up from his paper at Lucy who is writing furiously.
Do you wish me to come?
Well... whatever you'd like.
(a beat)
Thank you, no.
Very well then. (tipping his hat)
Good day, Miss Mercer. Lucy nods and Franklin exits. Then Louis tips his hat to ladies and follows him out.

9 A car pulls over and Franklin is first out, followed by Louis, walking at a brisk pace as they cross the opposite side of the street. Louis struggles to keep up while consulting a small appointment book.
At ten you've got a meeting with representatives from Pittsburgh Steel. Their bid on the ship building contract has already been turned in and is on your desk for approval.
FRANKLIN
What did I think of it? An AFRICAN-AMERICAN man steps off the curb, letting Frank and Louis pass. LOUIS
You had some problems with it. FRANKLIN
I better read it. Steel workers tend to vote democratic. Next. LOUIS
Lunch with Secretary Daniels. FRANKLIN
Must I? LOUIS
He's your boss. FRANKLIN
Anything else? LOUIS
(a beat) What if she'd said yes? FRANKLIN
Who? Louis shoots him a look that says "you know who." LOUIS
People know. It's time to stop. FRANKLIN
I can handle my own affairs, Louis. LOUIS
Not this one. This is Washington, D.C., not the Harvard Club. (off-put by Franklin's arrogance) How can you be so cavalier? FRANKLIN
You say that like it's a bad thing. Louis takes a quick last drag on his cigarette and follow him inside a building.

10 A large grandfather clock reads 3:00. The sound of a key in the front door turns and Franklin quietly enters. His hair is a mess and his clothing is slightly askew. As he comes through the hall two eyes shine in the darkne They belong to Eleanor sitting rigidly on a settee, liste to the sound of Franklin's footsteps going up the stairs. 11
Franklin goes into his bedroom. Eleanor quietly comes up stairs and stops for a brief moment by Franklin's door, t goes off to her bedroom closing the door behind her.

12 Franklin lays sleeping in his bed as Eleanor enters quiet so as not to wake him. Carefully she picks up a set of keys on the dresser then turns and notices a packet of letters sitting on top of a open duffle bag. Tentatively she reaches for them. She brings the packet, with a piece of ribbon, up to her nose. She is shocked by their familiar scent. With trembling hands she unties the ribbon. Tears flood d her cheeks as she reads. Franklin opens his eyes.

13 Springwood is the three-story Roosevelt mansion. It is surrounded by a thousand acres of forests, fields, bridal paths and a glorious view of the Hudson River. THE FIVE ROOSEVELT CHILDREN are screaming on the front la playing a boisterous game of croquet.
14 SARA ROOSEVELT, 65, sits at the head of the table. She is for whom the expression "Grande Dame" was coined.
Franklin is at the opposite end of the table, looking pal Louis, as always, is by his side. Eleanor, like a prisoner who has accepted her fate, sits across from them, calm and composed.
I have offered Franklin his freedom.
And I have accepted.
(to Eleanor)
His freedom is not yours to offer!
I am in love with Miss Mercer, Mama.
Lord save us from fools in love.
Falling in love is out of the question. Why do you think men have mistresses? Duty. Duty to their families and their careers. Eleanor rises from the table.
Where do you think you're going?
It's obvious that my input in this matter is of little importance. She begins to exit the room, but Franklin is up like a sh
Babs!
Come back here! Both of you!
15 Franklin chases Eleanor. Midway up the stairs, she turns.
I don't know whether to hate you or thank you.
For what?
For forcing me to face my life honestly for the first time.
I didn't mean to hurt you, Babs.
You never do. You live your life skimming the surface... never aware of the attachments beneath. (finding her anger)
It must be a luxury. She goes up the stairs without looking back. 16
Franklin slowly walks back into the room.
Divorce will finish your career in politics. How do you intend to support yourself?
My trust fund.
Divorce Eleanor and there is no trust fund. Franklin turns away. He looks out the large picture windo and attempts to light a cigarette, but his hands shake.

We've come so far, boss. State Assembly, Assistant Secretary of the Navy -- all pages right out of Cousin Teddy's play book. We're on the road to the White House. Don't do this. Franklin sees his son, ELLIOT, 10, playing separately fro the rest of his siblings. Elliot looks up at his father a Franklin bares his best politician's smile at him. A ROAR begins to fill his ears. It becomes clearer that i the sound of a CROWD CHEERING.
Rose-velt! Rose-velt! Rose-velt!
17 CONVENTIONEERS shout out Franklin's name holding up PLACA emblazoned with:
Franklin BOLTS, running vigorously down the center aisle the hall lit by the circle of a spotlight. The CROWD goes wild over this unconventional entrance.
hen he reaches the edge of the stage he LEAPS onto it. Th final act of daring pushes the crowd into frenzy.
18 Smiling for no one. For everyone.
(breathless)
I humbly accept your nomination for Vice-President! The CROWD roars back in reaction to his less-than-humble
They say the best way to get   rid of a man is to have him run for   Vice- President. (he holds for the laugh)

You might well have asked my   cousin Teddy if that's how they got   rid of him! Franklin stands on the stage, the music rising, the crowd cheering. Slowly, the sound of the convention fades to something far more delicate...

19 A harp playing in an elegant tea room. The hushed tones o polite conversation wafts through the air. Franklin sits with his cousin, ALICE ROOSEVELT, 36, daugh of Teddy. Brilliant and acerbic, she would have had a car in politics had she been born a man.
ALICE
Of course you lost. A Roosevelt on the democratic ticket? Our ancestors are turning in their graves. FRANKLIN
Cousin Alice, if Teddy were alive he'd be a democrat -- and you know it. ALICE
Rubbish. But I do know one thing: You're exactly like him. My father was born wanting only one thing: to be President. FRANKLIN
And what's wrong with that? They both share a laugh. ALICE
Do you know what they're saying about you? Franklin's smile fades. FRANKLIN
No, but I'm sure you'll tell me. ALICE
They say F.D.R. stands for "featherduster." That you're a lightweight. A dilettante with no substance; no point of view. FRANKLIN
Is that what you think? ALICE
You lead with your vanity. You talk when you should listen. Unless these are the qualities of a democrat? F RANKLIN
The democratic party is the party of the people. I am a man of the people. ALICE
Darling, you're a Roosevelt. What do you know about people?
She leans in conspiratorially.
Of course, I can think of one person you did manage to find the time to invest in. A Miss Mercer, I believe?
Alice, stop.
Don't misunderstand me, Franklin. Being married to Eleanor I think you deserved some fun. But you made the right decision. Especially since Miss Mercer has gone on with her life.
What are you talking about?
Edward Rutherford is a wonderful catch for a girl like her.
(stunned)
She's married?
Last week. A small event, of course.
When I last heard she was governess to his children.
(with a smile)
And then love bloomed. As a "man of the people," I wouldn't be too hard on her, Franklin. We can't all have trust funds you know.
20 Franklin, Louis and a PHOTOGRAPHER disembark from a touri
We're not taking this defeat lying down, boss. We'll run you for Governor --
FRANKLIN
(kidding) Really? Of which state? Louis shoots him a look. LOUIS
Very funny. No, this buys you time. It buys you experience. FRANKLIN
What about Al Smith? LOUIS
He's vulnerable. You're still a fresh face, boss. We'll use that to our advantage. They walk down a hill towards some waiting Boy Scouts as PHOTOGRAPHER follows them. FRANKLIN
Boy Scouts, Louis? Hardly my political base. LOUIS
They've got parents. Besides they're photogenic. Franklin begins glad-handing the assembled group of mostl underprivileged children. FRANKLIN

Franklin Roosevelt, happy to meet you. Franklin masks his thinly veiled discomfort with an artificial good cheer. Meanwhile, Louis, in full politica mode, makes sure the L Photographer gets everything.
Over here! Franklin poses with two Scouts. The picture is taken. SCOUTMASTER
Okay, boys, lunch. Line up to wash! (to Franklin) Will you be joining us?
Of course!
Franklin steps into a line before a large communal water barrel and glances sideways at GUISEPPE, 9, an immigrant child of the city streets. He wears his uniform proudly a smiles at Franklin.
What's your name, son?
Guiseppe. Franklin puts his arm around Guiseppe, forcing the moment between them. He waits patiently as the cameras click awa
Guiseppe! Come sta, ragazzo?
(puzzled)

Okay, I guess. The SCOUTS begin washing their hands together in the wate barrel and Franklin joins in as Louis looks on admiringly As Guiseppe splashes some of the water on his face, Frank not to be outdone, does so as well. It's all for the came
21 A large but unpretentious house with a sweeping lawn that looks out over the icy waters of the Bay of Fundy. 22

Eleanor sits quietly on the front porch knitting -- in a world of her own. A few feet away -- also in a world of his own -- sits Lou overdressed for summer in a three piece suit. An overflow ashtray is by his side and piles of newspaper lie at his feet. He holds up a paper to Eleanor with the photo of Franklin the Boy Scouts.
He's a natural. Eleanor gives it a cursory glance then looks out to where Franklin and the children come bounding up the lawn.
Franklin and Elliot break out from the rest and begin rac up the lawn. Franklin, no match for his son's speed, lose He doubles over, trying to catch his breath. ELLIOT
Vae victis! ("Woe to the conquered!")
aught up in his victory, Elliot doesn't see Franklin snea up behind him and tackle him to the ground. FRANKLIN
Festina lente! ("Not so fast!") One by one the other children all pile on top of Franklin Elliot. ELEANOR
Dinner is in one half-hour! Come in and change, children! FRANKLIN
Up! Up, chicks! You heard your mother! Everyone runs up the porch stairs and into the house exce Franklin. ELEANOR
Go wash up. Utterly spent, Franklin lays on the grass, not moving. LOUIS
Hey, boss! Are you all right? Slowly, Franklin gets up and walks with great effort up t porch stairs. FRANKLIN
I'm fine. (re: her knitting) Oh, that's pretty, Babs. He puts his hand on Eleanor's shoulder and leans in to bu her cheek but Eleanor quickly stands. ELEANOR
I must check on dinner. There is a cursory formality to her words and little warm
Very well. She goes into the house. Louis then hands Franklin letter
Tired?
Of you? Never. Wearily, he sorts through the envelopes.
Why don't you nap before dinner?
Yes, dear. Franklin heads into the house leaning heavily against the screen door struggling for control.
23 Franklin lays on a chaise being examined by a DOCTOR, who leans over him holding out his hand.
Can you take my hand? Franklin tries, but can't. Almost his entire body is paralyzed. He can only breathe and blink. The Doctor glances at Eleanor, Louis and Sara indicating should follow him out.
24 As the door from the sun room opens onto the porch, Ellio there waiting. Seeing them coming, he dashes off into the yard so as not to be seen as Eleanor, Louis, Sara and the Doctor enter.
He has Infantile Paralysis. Polio. Sara sinks into a chair.
I knew it. I knew it. D
D
ELEANOR
thought it only struck children. OCTOR
Not necessarily. LOUIS
How did he get it? DOCTOR
Some experts believe it is linked to contaminated water. But that theory is speculative at best. LOUIS
It was the visit to that god damned Boy Scout Camp! DOCTOR
In all honesty you need to be looking forward, not back. ELEANOR
What is the prognosis? DR. LOVETT
The damage to his leg muscles is extensive. I suspect he will be paralyzed from the waist down. ELEANOR
Dear God. beat) And the children? DR. LOVETT
If they don't have any symptoms by now then they have been spared. Sara stands -- her bearing once again erect and proud. SARA
Then we must count our blessings. R. LOVETT

You will need to prepare yourselves. There is a deep depression that follows an illness of this magnitude. I'm afraid life as he knew it is over. Their discussion is suddenly interrupted by the sound of child crying. Eleanor rushes off the porch to the bushes.
25 Eleanor finds Elliot, having heard everything, curled up ball, weeping. She leans down and wraps her arms around h

A pink background covered in small white flowers with red centers and green leaves. There is a seam in the paper. A tiny white spot where glue has soaked through. PULL BACK TO REVEAL - Franklin in bed. This is all he stares at -- hour after hour after hour. His lips are dry. A glass of water sits tantalizingly on the night stand. H reaches for it but it's a few inches out of his reach. Slowly, he begins to rock his torso back and forth.
27 Sara, Eleanor and Louis are in heated conversation.
Now that politics are out of the question he can stay here at home with me.
But what kind of life is that?
I've rented him an office downtown. He can still practice law.
Why would you want to do that?
Because he needs it.
He can pursue a career, Mama.
A man as proud and vital as Franklin... you're inviting him to be hurt.
And you, Mr. RA(cont'd) SA Howe, engaged in the
fantasy of a political future for my son... is there nothing you won't do to keep your job? Sara leaves as Eleanor goes after her.
Mama! That's not fair!
28 Franklin, still rocking his torso, has now gained some momentum, managing to have moved just a few inches.
29 Sara busies herself arranging flowers.
What kind of life is it to be pitied and stared at?
What kind of life is it to be hidden away? I know you believe that what you are suggesting for Franklin is best. But I think you are making it harder for him.
I think I know what's best for Franklin. I am his mother!
And I am his wife. Sara stares at Eleanor in disbelief. Eleanor stares back unflinching.

30 Franklin reaches his arm towards the glass only to fall f the bed to the floor with a thud. Frustrated beyond words Franklin lunges at his wheelchair and shoves it across th floor letting out an anguished cry. In agony, from both the pain and the humiliation, he star up and fixes his gaze on the ornate ceiling overhead. Then, closing his eyes, a POUNDING in his head starts to louder and louder --

31 Franklin, on his back, his face and body drenched with sw is asleep in his bunk in the boat. He awakens to the soun the POUNDING. Voices are calling him accompanied by FISTS smashing at the door. He opens his eyes and is disoriente He tries to sit up -- momentarily forgetting that he can'

e lifts the sheet and visibly WINCES in disgust at the si of his crippled legs. BONES covered by FLESH with barely ounce of muscle. Finally the door BURSTS open.   Two young crewman, EUGENE STANLEY enter.

Mr. Roosevelt, we got a storm comin'! He lifts Franklin over his shoulder. Stanley grabs clothe pulls a set of long iron leg braces from a hook off the w Eugene grabs a bucket and holds Franklin up to urinate.
(while peeing)

Leave me here. Let the ocean swallow me up. Burial at sea. Perfect for a navy man. Stripped to his underwear Franklin is laid across the bun Eugene kneels and puts on Franklin's socks and shoes. The and Stanley slide on his braces and pants. Their hands zipper, clasp, buckle and tie. Each hand work synchronicity with the other. Clumsily they lift Franklin up, struggling under his weig
32 Eugene and Stanley carry Franklin off in the driving rain

33 Kerosene lamps light the diner which is filled with peopl mostly fishermen, seeking refuge from the coming storm. Franklin, soaked-to-the-skin and wrapped in a blanket, is being pushed through the door by Eugene in a wheelchair. The restaurant collectively pauses to take them.

Franklin is slowly wheeled across the restaurant. He shri from the stares of the patrons. A LITTLE GIRL eating with her parents gets excited when s sees Franklin's braces and points. Franklin gives her a h look and she is hurt. What he can't see is that under the table she wears a set braces like his. Franklin is wheeled up to his table and EUGENE and STANLE down with him. Louis enters resembling a drowned rat. He rips off his ha and raincoat and puts down his suitcase. FRANKLIN
(genuinely surprised) Louis? LOUIS
I never miss Florida in the rainy season. FRANKLIN
No letter? No wire? LOUIS
Why? Would you have answered it? FRANKLIN
What the hell are you doing here? LOUIS
Good to see you too. Nice whiskers. You look like Chester Arthur. FRANKLIN
Stanley, this is Mr. Howe. He gets sea-sick at the mere sight of a boat so he's probably happy that it's being Ldestroyed right now. OUIS
Boys, I need to talk to Mr. Roosevelt alone. Find your own breakfast. Here's a five spot. Make it a feast. They look at the money and take their leave. FRANKLIN
You're always so generous with my money.
LOUIS

You mean your mother's, don't you? The Waitress puts down two cups of coffee. Franklin pulls a flask and pours some into his cup. He then lights a cigarette and begins smoking, but doesn't offer one to Lo Without asking, Louis helps himself. FRANKLIN
So Mama financed this fool's errand, has she? Well, it's a waste of a trip. LOUIS
It was Eleanor's idea. Franklin's face is immobile. WAITRESS
What can I get you? LOUIS
I'd like some ham and eggs, sunny side up, please? (to Franklin) What's your fancy, boss? FRANKLIN
Nothing. I fancy nothing. LOUIS
He'll have the same. The Waitress grabs their menus and scurries away. Louis o his briefcase and hands Franklin a stack of mail. Frankli glances it, but doesn't open any. LOUIS
There are a few from your children. FRANKLIN
I can still read. Franklin flips through the mail and finds a letter that interests him, opening it. LOUIS
Your wife wants you to come home. (choosing his words) She's concerned. I'm concerned. This life on a boat... where is it getting you?
F
FRANKLIN
Getting me? For one thing, no one gets to see me and I don't get to see them. LOUIS
Don't say that. Everyone's waiting for you to come home. The kids... they're aching to see you. RANKLIN
(reading) Really? Louis looks sadly at his friend. LOUIS
What's that? FRANKLIN

skimming the letter) From George Foster Peabody. He owns a resort in rural Georgia for investment purposes. Hot springs or something. He claims that only recently a crippled boy swam in the waters and can walk again. LOUIS
Oh, for Chrissake... FRANKLIN
(reading)

The high magnesium content of these natural springs will hold anyone up. Although it is not a resort for infirm types I am extending you my personal invitation to come visit in the off- season." (putting the letter aside) I'm only welcome in the "off- season." Eugene and Stanley approach the table. EUGENE
Mr. Roosevelt, we got bad news. FRANKLIN
What?
F
STANLEY
It's the boat... it got banged up real bad tied to the dock. RANKLIN
How bad? STANLEY
I don't think you can stay there anymore. ranklin absorbs this. EUGENE
Maybe it's a blessing in disguise, Mr. Roosevelt. I don't know about you, but I'm homesick. FRANKLIN
And I'm sick of home. (to Louis) Where's the letter from Peabody? LOUIS
You can't be serious? He hands Franklin the letter who rereads it. FRANKLIN
Why not miracle waters? I've drunk the oil of monkey glands, been zapped with electricity and hung upside down in harnesses. After all that, this sounds downright peaceful. LOUIS
I can't quite picture you in the back woods of Georgia. FRANKLIN
Where do you picture me, Louis? LOUIS
1600 Pennsylvania Avenue. FRANKLIN
President, Louis? I can't visit the bathroom without a team of associates to help pull my pants down.
Give it a little time.
There's a reason they say a man runs for office. (a beat)
I'm going to Georgia.

34 Franklin and Eleanor sit next to one another. Franklin is shaved and cleaned up considerably. However, the tension between them is palpable. Eleanor kn furiously while talking. Franklin looks out the window at African-American FIELD HANDS hard at work in the red clay hills of Georgia.

James has been doing so much better now that Elliot has joined him at Groton. They've put their differences behind them and have become a real team. Franklin observes two YOUNG BOYS, African-American, runni alongside the slow-moving train.

Two peas in a pod. Last week they were both in the infirmary with the F         same cold. ranklin eyes a wagon pulled by a mule. The driver, a FARM takes off his hat and wipes his brow in the hot sun.

Meanwhile, any suggestion I make to Anna for her future -- she dismisses me. I am going to have to enlist your support in this, Franklin. She listens to you. She looks over at Franklin and sees that he is staring ou window, deep in thought -- not having heard a word she's

35 TOM LOYLESS, 39, stands waiting by a car dressed in a whi suit. Laconic, with a dry sense of humor, Tom is a man of words whose poker face hides a true desperation. He holds telegram from Franklin in his hand. As the train pulls in Tom looks for Franklin among the passengers making their exit. There are two different exits on the platform clearly mar WHITE and COLORED. Whites exit from the front of the trai and Blacks from the rear. LIONEL PURDY, tiny, and dressed in a mailman's uniform, approaches Tom. Of indeterminate age and dubious intellec his mail bag is almost as big as he is.
Someone important?
You might say so, Lionel.
Who?
A Mr. Roosevelt.
Teddy?
(patiently)
No, he's dead.
Oh. The STATIONMASTER approaches.
Tom, your guest needs some assistance. We're gonna need some able-bodied men to move him.
(to Lionel)
Go over to the livery stable...
... and get the Collier boys.

36 Franklin exits the train slung in a fireman's carry over shoulder of ROY COLLIER, African-American, 29. His brothe PETE, 27, is close behind, carrying luggage -- both hover around 6' 4". Tom approaches. Franklin attempts to hide his embarrassme with good cheer.
Hello! Hello! Mr. Loyless?
Tom, Mr. Roosevelt.
Then you'd better call me Franklin. Still in the fireman's carry, Franklin extends his hand f Tom to shake.
Franklin.
And this is the Misses.
Call me Eleanor.
Pleased to make your acquaintance. Roy then carries him over to Tom's car and gingerly place him inside. Pete follows.
(to Tom)
There's a trunk and a chair with the wheels, too.
I'll send a wagon right over.
We got a wagon, sir.
37 Tom drives Franklin in front, Eleanor sits in the back.
Pine trees tower over the sides of the dirt road. In occasional clearings, Franklin spies barefoot children playing out in front of broken-down shacks. They stop the play to look at the car.
(covering his discomfort)
Beautiful country.
How long have you been manager of the Inn?
Not long. They BANG over a large pothole. They all fly up and land
Got any paved roads?
No we don't.

38 Tom's car turns into a driveway. Franklin has a brochure "The Meriwether Inn" opened in his lap. He tries to spy t building through the trees but cannot. He looks back at the brochure. The picture is of a lavish Victorian Hotel and the words, "Our renowned mineral hot springs can cure whatever ails you!" Franklin looks up and sees a three-story hideous green an yellow monstrosity leaning slightly to one side. Paint is peeling everywhere. What once were flower beds are overgr with weeds. The car pulls to a stop.

You'll have a great deal of privacy. There are only a few guests right now as it's the off- season... I'm hoping to make some improvements by next Spring -- Franklin puts out his arm preventing Tom from getting out the car.
(panicked)
I... I can't stay here. This place is a wreck.
Franklin!
Look on the bright side. Most of your time will be spent in the water. (a beat)
It's true, we've fallen on some hard times...
Hard times? This is a disaster! It should be condemned! Tom's southern manners are being put to the test, but he stays remarkably calm.
Yes, we've seen better days. (a beat)
But then I imagine so have you. Franklin blinks incomprehensibly at Tom and what he has j said.
I'm happy to drive you back to the train station right now, if that's what you want. They lock eyes. Franklin wonders if Tom's bluffing, but h can't tell.
(in a low voice)
Fire. I'm frightened of fire. I can't get out if I'm upstairs.
We've got options.
39 Tom's car is now parked in front of a group of small cottages. Roy and Pete's horse drawn wagon is behind it.
40 Tom and Pete open a set of shutters over the windows of a tiny cottage. Franklin and Eleanor sit in the car, watching.
41 Sheets cover the furniture, cobwebs span the beams and du particles fill the air. As Tom maneuvers the wheelchair through the front door, Franklin notices a broken window.
(caustic)
Well ventilated, at least. Roy enters with a suitcase.
Where do you want this, Mr. Roosevelt?
The bedroom, Roy, thank you. He looks after Roy as he exits.
Tom, this young man appears quite competent. Would you ask him if he'd like to stay on as my valet?
(politely)
Why don't you ask him yourself? He tips his hat and goes outside.
42 Pete, alone, drives the wagon past the Inn and out onto t road.
43 Eleanor stands in the middle of the tiny living room stun by the squalor. She speaks to Franklin who is changing in other room.
This is madness.
No doubt.

e takes in their uncomprehending expressions.

68 Roy is spotting Franklin as he pulls himself along a set parallel bars. Eleanor observes as Franklin uses his arms drag his legs behind him.

Well, you're here. And we're here. Together... we'll think of something. Franklin looks to Tom and gestures for him to come closer

No one's asking anything of you! FRANKLIN
Of course they are! TOM
Do you know what it took for most of them to get here? FRANKLIN

My God, you're afraid of these people. FRANKLIN
Afraid? What you're talking about? TOM
You look at them with the same repulsion and pity as everyone else. FRANKLIN

You don't want to be around them because then that would make you one of them, wouldn't it? Franklin furiously wheels himself back towards the cottag getting stuck on the dirt path along the way. FRANKLIN

Out of my way! Get out of my goddamn way! Franklin wheels himself off.

e hands Franklin a worn newspaper clipping from his pocke The headline reads: "FRANKLIN ROOSEVELT SWIMS HIS WAY TO

Knoxville.
TOM

Roy, take him to the car. As Roy lifts Fred in his arms, Franklin wheels himself to engine car. Tom follows as they approach the CONDUCTOR. FRANKLIN
Who in their right mind let's a child ride in the baggage car! You could have killed that boy. CONDUCTOR

(quietly)

What do you mean? TOM

For Fred?
(pointedly)
